The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.

For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
Does the concept of a/an Order of a group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Product Notation in Monoids to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of the Order of a group pertains to the number of elements in a group, whether finite or infinite. This concept is primarily concerned with the cardinality of the set that forms the group. On the other hand, the Product Notation in Monoids deals with the operation of multiplication (or any associative binary operation) of elements within a monoid. The definition of product notation in monoids does not require any knowledge of the total number of elements in the monoid; it only requires that the elements belong to the monoid and that the monoid operation is associative. Therefore, the concept of the order of a group (or monoid) is not necessary for defining or understanding the product notation in monoids. The product notation can be defined and used regardless of whether the monoid is finite or infinite, and irrespective of the actual number of elements in the monoid.
